abstract.p: This is a collection of the materials (outside of the textbook) we will use in class to guide you on your journey through MATH 110. The textbook used in the course will be Functions Modeling Change 6th edition by Connally, et al.

introduction.p: This is a collection of the materials (outside of the textbook) we will use in class to guide you on your journey through MATH 110.

solution.p: We would say that H a function of t because the temperature depends on the day. We cannot say that t a function of H because the result would have one input that produced 2 outputs. For example 77^{\circ}F corresponds to two different days (t=2 and t=4).

exercise.p: If the function y=f(x) represents a child's height (y in inches)as a function of her age (x in years), interpret the statement f(4)=42.

solution.p: The mathematical statement f(4)=42 indicates that at age 4 years, the child is 42 inches tall.

exercise.p: Let f(x) = x^2-3x+7. Compute the average rate of change from x=1 to x=4. Visualize the average rate of change using the line between the two points (1,f(1)) and (4,f(4)).

hint.p: How many units does the line segment go up as you move one unit to the right?

solution.p: The average rate of change is \frac{f(4)-f(1)}{4-1} = \frac{11-5}{3}=2 . We can see it from the line segment above. As we go to the right one unit, we go up 2 units.

exercise.p:
The total number of Netflix subscribershttps://www.businessinsider.com/netflix-subscribers-chart-2017-1 in a given year between 2010 and 2015 is given by the table below.
\begin{array}{c|c|c|c|c|c|c} \text{Year} & 2010 & 2011 & 2012 & 2013 & 2014 & 2015 \\ \hline \text{Subscribers (in millions)} & 20.01 & 23.53 & 33.27 & 44.35 & 57.39 & 74.76 \\ \end{array}
Determine the rate of change of the number of Netflix subscribers between 2010 and 2013.
Determine the rate of change of the number of Netflix subscribers between 2013 and 2015, and compare to you answer from part (a). What do you think this says about Netflix's growth?

ol.li:
Using the rate of change formula we get
RoC_{2010\leq x \leq 2013} = \frac{44.35-20.01}{2013-2010} = \frac{24.34}{3} = 8.11\overline{3} \text{ million subscribers per year}

exercise.p: After being on Instagram for a while, Sam started keeping track of her followers. Let N represent the number of followers she has on Instagram at time t in months since she started keeping track.

ol.li: Could this function be linear? (Check the rate of change over each interval.)
What is the slope of this linear function?
What does the slope mean in real world terms?
Write a formula for N as a function of t. (What is the vertical intercept?)
What does your vertical intercept represent in real world terms?

li.p: Using the rate of change formula we get
From this data, the function looks linear as the rate of change is constant over every interval.

ol.li: The slope is 25 as the slope is the constant rate of change of a linear function.
The slope represents the change in followers per month. That is, the number of followers increases by 25 per month.
The vertical intercept here is 70 which represents the initial number of followers when Sam started keeping track.

exercise.p: The enrollment at JU is given by the following graph of a linear function where S represents the number of students, and t represents the number of years since 2000.

ol.li: Using the two given points on the graph, determine the rate of change (slope) of the linear function.
How many students were there in the year 2000?
Determine a formula for S as a function of t

li.p: If the number of students increases by 36 each year, then going back one year from 2001 to 2000 should result in a decrease in 36 from the 2636 students that were at JU in 2000. Hence, there were 2600 students in 2000.
Using the two pieces of data above

exercise.p: Compute a formula for the linear function graphed below.

solution.p: The slope is \frac{22-13}{5-2} = \frac{9}{3} = 3 Using the point-slope form we get y-13 = 3(x-2) \quad \Rightarrow \quad y=3x+7

ol.li: Find the equation of a line that is parallel to y=4x-2 that passes through the point (2,5).
Find the equation of a line that is perpendicular to y=3x+7 that passes through the point (3,5).
Since the lines are parallel, the new slope is 4. Using the point-slope form we get y-5=4(x-2) \quad \Rightarrow \quad y=4x-3
Since the lines are perpendicular, the new slope is \frac{-1}{3}. Using the point-slope form we get y-5=\frac{-1}{3}(x-3) \quad \Rightarrow \quad y=\frac{-1}{3}x+6

exercise.p: The profit from selling widgets at a widget factory is given by the following table

ol.li: Assuming that profit is linear, find a formula for profit as a function of number of widgets sold.
Why do you think that the vertical intercept (your b value) is negative?

We can use any two points here, so I'll use (5,1) and (10,7). m = \frac{7-1}{10-5}=\frac 65 = 1.2 To compute the equation of the line, we use the point-slope form y-1 = 1.2(x-5) \quad \Rightarrow \quad y = 1.2x-5
When first making a product, there will be initial costs that are only recovered once you start selling your product. Thus, profit will start out negative.

exercise.p: The store Bed, Bath, and Beyond offers two types of coupons, (type A) $5 dollars off a purchase of $15 dollars or more, and a (type B) 20% off coupon.

li.p: Model both coupons by linear functions. In this case, discounted price is your dependent variable, and price before the coupon is your independent variable.
Graph both functions and make a recommendation of when to use which coupon. To make it simpler, you can assume that the purchase you are making is $15 or more.
Let x represent the undiscounted price A = x-5 \quad B = x-0.2x \text{ or } 0.8x

Note: use y as your output variable here, because Desmos won't understand A and B. We see visually that the $5 is better if the price is below $25, and the 20% off is better if the price is above $25. x-5 = 0.8x \quad \Rightarrow \quad 0.2x=5 \quad \Rightarrow \quad x = 25

section.title: Section 1.6 - Fitting Linear Functions to Data

exercise.p: Look at the data below, and decide whether you think the slope is positive or negative and if the correlation is close to 1 or -1. Then compute using the technique we learned using Desmos.

solution.p: Here, the values seem to form something close to a line with a positive slope, so the correlation should also be positive. It reports a positive slope of m=1.01 and a positive r value of 0.9909 meaning a strong linear relationship.

exercise.p: Look at the data below, and decide whether you think the slope is positive or negative and if the correlation is close to 1 or -1. Then compute using the technique we learned using Desmos.

solution.p: Here, the values seem to form something close to a line with a negative slope, so the correlation should also be negative. It reports a positive slope of m=-1.095 and a positive r value of -0.978 meaning a strong linear relationship.

exercise.p: Look at the data below, and decide whether you think the slope is positive or negative and if the correlation is close to 1 or -1. Then compute using the technique we learned using Desmos.

solution.p: Here, the values seem to form a semicircle which is not linear. It reports a positive slope of m=0.12 and a positive r value of 0.2456 meaning a weak linear relationship.

section.title: Project #1: Linear Regression
section.p: In track running, there are several races that are approximately a mile. In high school track the distance often used is 1600 meters, as it is four times around the standard track when running in the innermost lane. Historically, the mile (which is approximately 1609.344 meters) has been significant in running with Roger Bannister breaking the four minute barrier in 1954. However, in the modern Olympics, the distance most commonly run that is close to a mile is the 1500 meters.

This race has been run in every summer Olympic games since 1896. The summer Olympics have been held every four years except in 1916, 1940, and 1944. Oddly, the Olympics were also held out of schedule in 1906, and the governing body of the Olympics doesn't recognize the medals received during these games.

The race has been an Olympic event for men longer than it has for women, so the data goes back further. In this project you will be making predictions based on a linear regression formula for the winning times. So first copy the men's and women's data into Excel or Desmos, taking care to convert all times into seconds. Graph both sets of data on the same set of axes and add trend lines. Have Excel/Desmos display both equations and the trend lines.

Before using the trend lines, write the formulas for both using proper function notation. Let f be the function for the men's times and g be the function for the women's times. Completely explain what the input and output of each function is. Also discuss how the R-values for each function affect your confidence in using them. Excel will report R squared rather than R, so you will need to calculate R from it. Is R positive or negative? Why?

After discussing the formulas and their R-values, explain the meanings of the basic geometric properties of each trend line. In particular, using the context of the problem, give the practical meaning of the slopes, vertical intercepts, and horizontal intercepts of each line. Do all of your answers and explanations seem reasonable? If not, why not?

Following the discussion of the geometric properties, use the trend lines to answer all of the following questions. When answering each question, use proper mathematics and function notation when presenting the necessary algebra to answer each question.

ol.li: What are the meanings of f(1980) and g(1980)? How reliable is each result?

You will notice there are some years missing in the data for the men when there normally would have been Olympics if the four year cycle was followed. Why might these scores be missing? Use your trend line to predict the winning times if these Olympics had been held. How much do you trust these results?
In what year would have or will the winning times for the men and women be the same?
What times do you predict will be necessary to win the men's and women's in the 2020 Olympics?
Use your trend lines to approximate at which Olympics the men and women will break the 3 minute mark. Do you believe your predictions?

section.p: The final paper must be type written including all necessary formulas. To type formulas in Word, use Insert/Equation. This should be written as a paper and not a long homework problem. In particular, do not number parts, instead write in sentences and paragraphs and use section headings if appropriate. Each paper should include a title page, an introduction, a main body, and a conclusion. As a general guide after reading the introduction, the reader should know what you are going to do, and why, without referring to this assignment sheet. The main body should consist of answers to all of the questions, a discussion of each, and all the necessary formulas and algebra to find them. Use your book as a guide on how to properly display equations. Make sure you define every variable you use immediately before or after it first appears. Also the Excel graph you created should be within the text (not at the end) and referred to by the text when you are initially explaining your functions. The conclusion should summarize what you learned. Specifically, what you learned about the winning times using your trend lines, not what you learned about mathematics (that is just hopefully a side effect). Throughout adopt the tone that these are things you set out to find out on your own and are reporting your findings, not like you are responding to questions.

exercise.p: Let f(x) = x^2-9.

ol.li: Compute f(0).
Solve f(x) = 0.
Compute f(\blacksquare).
Compute and simplify f(x+\pi).
x^2-9= 0 \quad \Rightarrow \quad x^2=0 \quad \Rightarrow \quad x = \pm \sqrt{9} = \pm 3 .
f(\blacksquare)=\blacksquare^2-9.

exercise.p: Marvin the Martian has height given by h(t) = 13+\frac{t^2}{2} where t is the number of years since Marvin was born and height is in inches.

ol.li: How tall was Marvin at birth (time zero)?
When will Marvin be 21 inches tall?
What is the meaning of the quantity h(5)? What is its units?
h(0)=13+\frac{0^2}{2}=13 inches tall
We solve 21=13+\frac{t^2}{2} which is equivalent to 8=\frac{t^2}{2} or 16=t^2. This is true when t=\pm 4, but only t=4 years makes sense in this context.
h(5)=13+\frac{5^2}{2} = 25.5 inches and it represents Marvin's height at 5 years old.

exercise.p: Answer the following questions about the function f(x) using its graph below.

worksheet.exercise:
For the following questions use the function y=f(x) graphed below.
Compute the domain and range of f.
Compute f(2).
Find values of x so that f(x)=2.
The domain is -4.5\leq x \leq because this represents the x values present in the graph. The range is -2\leq y \leq 2 because this represents the y values present in the graph.
f(2)=-1 as this is the y coordinate that corresponds to the x coordinate 2.
From the graph it looks like x=-1, x=3 are the values with f(x)=2. These can be checked by computing f(-1),f(3) with Desmos.

The graph the function f(x)= x^2 is drawn on the on the following axes.
On the same axes, graph f(x)+2. (What is f(x)+2 you say? f(x)+2 = x^2+2.)
On the same axes, graph f(x)-2.
Make a conjecture (educated guess) as to what adding or subtracting a positive constant from a function does to its graph.
As can be seen from the graph above, this results in a shift up by 2.
As can be seen from the graph above, this results in a shift down by 2.
Adding a positive constant shifts up by as many units, whereas subtracting a positive constant shifts the graph downward.

The graph the function g(x)= \vert x \vert is drawn on the on the following axes.
On the same axes, graph g(x+2).
On the same axes, graph g(x-2).
Make a conjecture (educated guess) as to what adding or subtracting a positive constant from the input of a function does to its graph.
We see that this results in a shift left by 2 units.
We see that this results in a shift right by 2 units.
Adding to the input shifts the function's graph left, whereas subtracting shifts it right.

section.title: Section 2.5 - Preview of Composite and Inverse Functions

worksheet.exercise:
Let C=f(w) be the cost in dollars producing w widgets in our widget factory. What do the quantities f(500) and f^{-1}(20000) represent in terms of widgets and dollars?
The quantity f(500) represents the cost of producing 500 widgets. The quantity f^{-1}(20000) represents the number of widgets that can be produced for $20000.

Below is a graph of f(x).
If g(x)=x^2+3, compute g(f(1)).
Compute f(f(-4)).
Since the y coordinate of the point with x=1 is 0, g(f(1))=g(0)=0^2+3=3.
Note that f(-4)=0 as the function crosses the x axis there. Hence, f(f(-4))=f(0)=-0.5.

The radioactive isotope Radon-222 decays at a rate of 16.7\% per day.From https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radioactive_decay
Write a function giving the mass M of a 500 gram sample after a time t in days.
How much will we have remaining after 3 days?
(hard) When will we only have half of our initial sample remaining? (Hint: Look at the graph of your exponential function, and the graph of y=250.)
Since the quantity decreases by 16.7\% each day, there is 83.3\% remaining. M = g(t) = 500(.833)^t
g(3) = 500(.833)^3 \approx 289.005 \text{ grams}
We see that the curves intersect when t=3.793.

After a car is purchased, it loses value over time. For example, a $20000 car is worth only $8000 five years after it was purchased.
Assuming that the car loses its value exponentially, find a formula for value V as a function of time since it was purchased.
When will the car be worth $5000?
The starting value is $20000, so V = 20000b^t
Since the car is worth $8000 when t=5, 8000 = 20000b^5 \quad \Rightarrow \quad b^5 = \frac{8000}{20000} = .4 \quad \Rightarrow \quad b = \sqrt[5]{.4}
Thus, the function is V = 20000\left(\sqrt[5]{.4}\right)^t .
Graphing the exponential function and a horizontal line at 5000, we see that it takes approximately 7.565 years for the value of the car to reduce to $5000.

Find the equation of the exponential function passing through the points (1,6) and (4,24).
As the function is of the form y=a\cdot b^x, we see that 24=ab^4 \text{ and } 6=ab^1
Dividing the two equations yields \frac{24=ab^4}{6=ab^1} \quad \Rightarrow \quad 4 = b^3 \quad \Rightarrow \quad b = \sqrt[3]{4}
Now that we know b, we can find a by using one of the above equations 6=a\sqrt[3]{4}^1 \Rightarrow a = \frac{6}{\sqrt[3]{4}} y=\frac{6}{\sqrt[3]{4}}(\sqrt[3]{4})^x
(It would be a good idea to check by graphing).

Suppose the population of ants in my yard is given by A =f(t)= 100(1.12)^t where A represents the number of ants, and t is time in weeks since I started measuring.
Is the number of ants increasing or decreasing? By what percentage is it increasing/decreasing each week?
When will the population of ants reach 1000?
It is increasing because the growth factor 1.12 is greater than 1. It increases by 12% per week
According to the graph, during week 20 the ant population reaches 1000.

Surprise! You receive a $5000 bonus from your new job! You are deciding how you should invest this. (You really want to buy a new motorcycle.)
Option 1: A savings account that earns $12.1%$ compounded annually.
Option 2: A savings account that earns $12%$ compounded monthly.
Suppose that we invest in "Option 1". Write a formula for the balance of the account A after t years.
Suppose that we invest in "Option 2". Write a formula for the balance of the account B after t years.
What is the effective interest rate for "Option 2"? Which account would you invest in?
The motorcycle you want is $10000. How long will it take to save up that much using "Option 2"?
B_1 = 5000(1.121)^t
B_2 = 5000\left(1+\frac{.12}{12}\right)^{12t} = 5000(1.01)^{12t}
To compute the effective rate, we strip away the 5000 and plug in 1 for t to see the effect after 1 year. 1.01^{12} = 1.1268
This tells us that our effective rate is 12.68%
We see that the graph of our "Option 2" function and the horizontal line at $10000 intersect when t=5.805 meaning that it takes almost 6 years for us to reach the desired $10000

Without a calculator, compute the following
\log(10000)
\ln(e^3)
\log\left( \frac{1}{\sqrt{10}} \right)
e^{\ln 2}
\log(\sqrt{1000})
\log(10000) = 4 because 10^4=10000
\ln(e^3)=3 If we ask, what power of e it is, we see the answer is 3.
\log\left( \frac{1}{\sqrt{10}} \right)=-\frac 12 There are several ways to do this, but notice that we could look at it as \log(1)-log(\sqrt{10})=0-\frac 12 = -\frac 12
e^{\ln 2}=2 by our fifth log property
\log(\sqrt{1000})=\frac 32 There are several ways to approach this, but using the fact that square root is the same as the \frac 12 power, \log(\sqrt{1000}) = \log(1000^{\frac 12}) = \frac 12 \log(1000) = \frac 12 \cdot 3 = \frac 32

exercise.p: Using our logarithm properties, solve the equation

solution.p: The key to this one is taking the natural logarithm of both sides (a preview of the next section).
We get the second equality by asking "what power of e is it?"

worksheet.exercise:
The population of Smallville grows from 11000 in the year 2010 to 13000 in the year 2013.
Write a formula for the population P as an exponential function of t, the number of years since 2010.
When will the population double in size?
We start with what we know, namely that P=11000b^t as the initial quantity is 11000. We then use the fact that P is 13000 when t=3 to see 13000=11000b^3 \quad \Rightarrow \quad \frac{13000}{11000} = b^3 \quad \Rightarrow \quad \sqrt[3]{\frac{13000}{11000}} = b P = 11000\left( \sqrt[3]{\frac{13000}{11000}} \right)^t
We now set P equal to 22000 and solve for t 22000=11000\left( \sqrt[3]{\frac{13000}{11000}} \right)^t \quad \Rightarrow \quad 2 = \left( \sqrt[3]{\frac{13000}{11000}} \right)^t \ln(2) = t \cdot \ln \left( \sqrt[3]{\frac{13000}{11000}} \right) t = \frac{\ln(2)}{\ln \left( \sqrt[3]{\frac{13000}{11000}} \right)} \approx 12.45 \text{ years}

Convert the exponential function f(t)=3(0.5)^t to a function of the form f(t)=ae^{kt}. What do you notice about k in this scenario?
Here, we remember that b=e^k and since b=.5, we can use that to solve for k. 0.5=e^k \quad \Rightarrow \quad \ln(0.5)=\ln(e^k)=k
Note that \ln(0.5) \approx -0.6931 so f(t)=3e^{-0.6931t}
The thing that is different in this scenario is that we have a negative k value. This happens when the exponential function is decreasing

exercise.p: Determine the period, midline, and amplitude of the graph below
exercise.solution: The period of this graph is 4 (for me, I am measuring the distance between the peaks). The midline is halfway between the minimum (-3) and maximum (7) which is y=\frac{-3+7}{2}=2. The amplitude is the distance between the midline and the maximum which is 5.

exercise.p: Determine the period, midline, and amplitude of the graph below
exercise.solution: The period of this graph is 2 (for me, I am measuring the distance between the peaks). The midline is halfway between the minimum (-7) and maximum (-1) which is y=\frac{-7+-1}{2}=-4. The amplitude is the distance between the midline and the maximum which is 3.

section.title: Section 7.2 - The Sine and Cosine Functions

worksheet.exercise:
Conversions:
Convert 150^\circ to radians.
Convert \frac{7\pi}{4} radians to degrees.
150^\circ \cdot \frac{\pi}{180} = \frac{150\pi}{180}=\frac{5\pi}{6}
\frac{7\pi}{4} \cdot \frac{180}{\pi} = 315^\circ

Compute the following without a calculator.
\cos\left( \frac {3\pi}{4} \right)
\tan\left( 45^{\circ} \right)
\sin\left(150^{\circ}\right)
\cos\left( \frac {3\pi}{4} \right) = \cos(135^\circ) Using symmetry of the unit circle (draw the picture here), we get that \cos(135^\circ)=-\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}
\tan\left( 45^{\circ} \right) =\frac{\sin(45^\circ)}{\cos(45^\circ)} = \frac{\sqrt{2}/2}{\sqrt{2}/2}=1
Using symmetry we get that \sin\left(150^{\circ}\right) = \frac 12

What is the length of an arc that is cut off by an angle of 225^\circ in a circle of radius 4 feet?
First, we convert to radians 225^\circ \cdot \frac{\pi}{180} = \frac{5\pi}{4} , then we use the arc length formula s = r\theta = 4\cdot \frac{5\pi}{4} = 5\pi

section.title: Section 7.4 - Graphs of Sine and Cosine

exercise.p: Determine the midline and amplitude of the graph of y=3\sin(x)+1 below.
exercise.solution: The midline is y=1 and the amplitude is 3.

exercise.p: Determine the midline and amplitude of the graph of y=-2\cos(x)+4 below.
exercise.solution: The midline is y=4 and the amplitude is 2. (Note that it isn't -2, because distances cannot be negative).

worksheet.exercise:
For the following graphs of periodic functions, estimate the period, midline, and amplitude of the function. Then find the formula for the function. (Hint, the period is always either a multiple of \pi or a whole number).
(challenge)
The period is \pi, the midline is y=2, the amplitude is 4, and a possible formula is y=4\sin(2x)+2
The period is 2, the midline is y=-1, the amplitude is 1, and a possible formula is y=\cos(\pi x)-1
The period is \frac{2\pi}{3}, the midline is y=10, the amplitude is 20, and a possible formula is y=-20\cos(3 x)+10
The period is 2\pi, the midline is y=2, the amplitude is 3, and a possible formula is y=3\cos( x+0.5)+2. This one has a shift left by 0.5.
